Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Evaluating Ebola Message Effects over Time: Risk Perceptions, Trust in and Attributions of Responsibility to Institutions, Personal Behavior and Policy Support

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
While Ebola threatens a major catastrophe in West Africa, its public health impacts in the U.S. are likely to be minor, shaped more by fear than transmission of the virus. The effect, however, on Americans' trust in public health authorities, and thus the impacts on future epidemics, among other impacts, may be much larger. Research to track changes in public views on Ebola risk and management performance, especially their impacts on trust and attribution of responsibility to varied institutions (e.g., Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Department of Health and Human Services, Obama administration, Congress, hospitals), and individual medical professionals and travelers from West Africa, is vital to help foretell public responses to future epidemic threats. Given the diverse and conflicting messages about Ebola risks and institutional performance now present, we also must understand how such messages affect public interpretations of Ebola risk and institutional performance. Results can help improve public health management and communication, plus help integrate theory on risk perception, trust in institutions, attribution of responsibility to institutions, and risk communication.

This study involves five surveys over 6 months with the same randomly sampled set of people from a diverse national online panel, exploiting the strength of a longitudinal survey experiment to assess causes of change over time. The experimental part of the study tests effects of alternative messages over this extended period, tracking their interactions with interpretive screens provided by trust and attributions of responsibility. Two messages concern the 21-day quarantine based on WHO recommendations: one message that repeats the authorities' reassurance that this quarantine is long enough that the affected person will not become symptomatic after release, and one that warns (based on expert analyses) of small but non-zero risks that symptoms will appear beyond this period. Besides testing the effect of the latter message on judged risk, trust, and support for the 21-day quarantine limit, the study also tests the inoculation strategy of stimulating counter-arguments to reduce panic effects of later counter-attacks on the quarantine period. A third message, also an inoculation message, stressrd capabilities of the public health system despite inevitable mistakes, to see how this affects trust and responsibility-attribution ratings. In pre-event conditions this kind of inoculation seems to reduce public over-reaction to scary [terrorism] events, but in the midst of ongoing management of Ebola may be counter-productive. The final message will review arguments on specific policies (e.g., how to keep people from Ebola-afflicted West African nations out of the U.S., or from spreading disease while here). Varied belief, attitude and behavioral intention measures tracks effects of these manipulations, and tests potential moderators (e.g., worldview, affect, political ideology and partisanship). Finally, the research includes the first probe of how perceived relations among institutions affect trust and attributions (e.g., belief that CDC was free to act against Ebola without constraints from other institutions may increase its judged responsibility for subsequent failures of performance).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined beliefs, attitudes, and intentions and behaviors of Americans about Ebola over time, and factors explaining these reactions, featuring a longitudinal study of 625 people answering each of five surveys from December 2014, one month after the second (and last) death from Ebola in the U.S., to May 2015. A nationally representative sample also answered many of the same questions in May 2015, to see how concerned Americans were six months after that last death. A separate experiment in November 2014 tested reactions to information that a small number of people could get symptoms, and thus become infectious, more than 21 days after infection with Ebola.

Intellectual Merit

This study tracked how public views did and did not change over time as a (largely hypothetical for the U.S.) disease incident unfolded. For example, only perception of U.S. risk changed over time, while personal or global risk ratings did not. People who felt a large Ebola outbreak was likely in the U.S., thought the U.S. experienced a near-miss for an outbreak during this period, dreaded Ebola, and followed Ebola news had higher perceived risk for the U.S. at the outset, but as perceived risk declined over time it was the news-followers and the near-miss believers whose risk judgments fell fastest, with risk judgments falling slower than average among large-outbreak believers. These varied reactions—stability of personal and global risk ratings perhaps reflecting the tiny U.S. incidence of Ebola, and thus disappearing when the number or geographical distribution of U.S. cases grows; U.S. risk ratings due to variables associated with media effect, psychometric, and mental models of hazard evolution theories of risk—and both risk amplification and attenuation with the same people over time (e.g., media exposure; belief in a near miss) extend our limited understanding of how risk perceptions change over time.

The stability of trust judgments over time fits with findings from cross-sectional trust asymmetry studies that people continue to trust or distrust a hazard manager despite a single bad or good event, respectively. Previous research showed how their individual attributes affect trust in hazard managers one at a time. This is the first study to show that views of relationships among hazard managers affect confidence in the overall system’s ability to protect people, and apparent malleability in citizen judgments of such relationships suggests people tend to have no or sketchy mental models of them.

This study identified both a high rate of stigmatizing actions (13-16% reported they had avoided West Africans or people back from helping with Ebola in West Africa, places or transportation modes) and intentions, but also variance based upon whether one actually had the opportunity to stigmatize (e.g., frequent flyers were more likely to avoid commercial flights or Ebola-screening airports). There was both convergence in factors in stigmatizing (in the two May 2015 surveys), and divergence (e.g., following Ebola news increased stigmatizing in December 2014, but decreased it in May, perhaps reflecting different media content at these times).

Broader Impacts

This study helps inform public health communication in future infectious disease incidents or epidemics. Officials can focus on specific issues that merit attention when they know their worries that the American public was panicking over Ebola were overwrought (e.g., low personal risk perception), but that there were concerns over a U.S. outbreak, and actions and intentions to stigmatize (e.g., six months after the last Ebola death in the U.S., two-thirds or more of those in the representative sample in May 2015 intended to stigmatize people or places in any future Ebola outbreak, whether in Africa or the U.S.).
